Award.AwardTitle: CHS: Small: Narrative-Based Training Simulations Using Theory of Mind

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will create a framework for simulation-based training that supports a learner's exploration and replay, and will exercise theory of mind skills, in order to deliver the full promise of social skills training. The term Theory of Mind (ToM) refers to the human capacity to use beliefs about the mental processes and states of others. In order to train social skills, there has been a rapid growth in narrative-based simulations that allow learners to role-play social interactions. However, the design of these systems often constrains the learner's ability to explore different behaviors and their consequences. Attempts to support more generative experiences face a combinatorial explosion of alternative paths through the interaction, presenting an overwhelming challenge for developers to create content for all the alternatives. Rather, training systems are often designed around exercising specific behaviors in specific situations, hampering the learning of more general skills in using ToM. This research seeks to solve this problem through three contributions: (1) a new model for conceptualizing narrative and role-play experiences that addresses generativity, (2) new methods that facilitate content creation for those generative experiences, and (3) an approach that embeds theory of mind training in the experience to allow for better learning outcomes. This research is applicable to complex social skill training across a range of situations: in schools, communities, the military, police, homeland security, and ethnic conflict.

This research begins with a paradigm shift that re-conceptualizes social skills simulation as the learner rehearsing a role instead of performing a role. This shift will exploit Stanislavsky's Active Analysis (AA), a performance rehearsal technique that explicitly exercises Theory of Mind skills. Further, AA's decomposition into short rehearsal scenes can break the combinatorial explosion over long narrative arcs that exacerbates content creation for social training systems. The research will then explore using behavior fitting and machine learning techniques on crowd sourced data as way to semi-automate the development of multi-agent simulations for social training. The research will assess quantitatively and qualitatively the ability of this approach (a) to provide experiences that support exploration and foster ToM use and (b) to support acquiring crowd sourced data that can be used to craft those experiences using automatic methods. This project is unique in combining cutting edge work in modeling theory of mind, interactive environments, performance rehearsal and crowd sourcing. This multidisciplinary collaboration will enable development of a methodology for creating interactive experiences that pushes the boundaries of the current state of the art in social skill training. Reliance on crowd sourcing provides an additional benefit of being able to elicit culturally specific behavior patterns by selecting the relevant crowd, allowing for both culture-specific and cross-cultural training content.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Effective social interaction is a critical human skill. To train social skills, there has been a rapid growth in narrative-based simulations that allow learners to role-play social interactions with virtual characters, and, in the process, ideally learn social skills necessary to deal with socially complex situations in real-life. Examples include training systems to address doctor-patient interaction, cross-cultural negotiation, and childhood bullying.

Although interactive narrative systems represent a major advance in training, their designs often do not provide learners with the flexibility to replay scenarios with sufficient variety in choices to support experiential based learning and achievement of proficiency. Attempts to create more generative experiences face various challenges. First, the combinatorial explosion of alternative narrative paths poses an overwhelming challenge to create content for all the paths, especially if there are long narrative arcs. Second, the models of narrative systems need to be re-conceptualized to allow for the flexibility needed in more generative approaches.

The goal of this project was to develop techniques that would facilitate the creation of narrative systems for social skills training that are generative and support replay. Achieving this requires: (1) a new model for conceptualizing narrative/role-play experiences that are generative, (2) new methods to facilitate extensive content creation for those experiences and (3) an approach that embeds theory of mind training in the experience to support better learning outcomes.

Our approach began with a paradigm shift that re-conceptualizes social skill simulation as rehearsing and improvising roles instead of performing a role. We adapted Stanislavsky?s Active Analysis (AA) technique as the design basis for social simulation training. AA was developed to help theatre actors rehearse a script or text. AA has two attributes especially relevant to developing social skills training systems. First, AA is explicitly designed to foster an actor?s conceptualization of the beliefs, motivations and behavior of the other actors. In other words, AA was developed to engender Theory of Mind reasoning in actors and is therefore especially relevant to social skills role-play training. Second, by adopting AA to simulation based social skills training, the emphasis shifts to developing short scenes that emphasize variability and re-playability. Decomposition into short rehearsal scenes helps break the combinatorial explosion that exacerbates content creation for social training systems designed with long narrative arcs. Short scene rehearsals also support users replaying scenes, possibly in different roles with different virtual actors, and to directly experience in subsequent scenes the larger social consequences of behaviors. In other words, instead of performing a role as in traditional training simulations, the learner is placed in a context of rehearsing a scene, possibly repeatedly, possibly in different roles.

AA by itself doesn't address the entire content creation issue. It, however, provides a basis for experience design that enables crowd sourcing and ToM constructs to generate content for rich, coherent interactive experiences. Using AA, we developed a machine learning framework that can be used to crowd source data and build that experience, thus addressing the content creation issue. Specifically, the acquisition problem was broken into 3 phases, acquiring social narrative content from the crowd by leveraging ideas from AA, forming the action space of an agent and finally using a novel iterative, active machine learning approach that leveraged the crowd to acquire generative socially interactive agents that could engage users in an open-ended social interaction. For each of these phases, alternative approaches were explored, systematically evaluated across multiple distinct social scenarios, with an emphasis of exploring whether crowd workers could facilitate the processes. 

In addition to the use of crowd sourcing and machine learning, the project also explored the development of methods to facilitate content development of interactive narratives while focusing on a good user experience. In order to address this problem, a study was conducted about agency and its relation to user experience with an eye to developing content development tools. The results of the study showed much variation on how users interpret and experience agency, deriving from factors related to structure of the narrative, feedback delivery, as well as the way the narrative forks or branches are based on or not based on interaction. A visualization tool was developed to help designers visualize these factors in an effort to help them tune their design based on these factors. She then developed a set of metrics related to these factors that can provide a quantitative assessment of the interactive narrative, in regards to user experience, agency and perception of agency. This work can in the future be linked to the work of the above Crowd/ML techniques to produce a way to assess and develop content that is more tuned to the user experience.
